title: An Unusual Location of a Pilar Sheath Acanthoma
patient: The case we present here is about a 63-year-old Caucasian male presented to our office complaining of a bump in his right earlobe for several years. He reported the ability to express contents out of the bump frequently, but denied any previous trauma to the area, including ear piercings, or any previous treatment. In addition, he reported a benign past medical history.\nPhysical exam revealed a 4 mm skin colored nodule with a small central opening located on his right earlobe []. Provisional diagnoses included: epidermal inclusion cyst, dilated pore of Winer, and a trichofolliculoma.\nA 4 mm punch biopsy was performed and sent for routine H and E staining, which revealed bulbous aggregations of isthmic epithelial cells containing sebaceous ducts emanating from a dilated infundibulum and extending into the dermis, consistent with a pilar sheath acanthoma []. In addition to being diagnostic, the biopsy was also curative, and no further treatment was required.
